question_text: Which disease-modifying therapy (DMT) requires pre-antiviral agent prophylaxis?

options.A: Fingolimod

question_text: In a case of primary progressive multiple sclerosis with typical MRI features and normal cerebrospinal fluid, what is known to increase walking speed?

options.A: 4-pyridine derivative (Dalfampridine/4-aminopyridine)
patient with optic neuritis has an MRI of the spine that shows long-sequence enhancement and is OGB negative. What is the next step in management?

question_text: Which of the following is a classic presentation of Heerfordt syndrome?

options.A: Uveoparotid fever

young male patient with a known case of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) on natalizumab developed lower limb weakness and generalized numbness. Laboratory tests show positive anti-natalizumab antibodies, and MRI shows enhanced lesions. What is the recommended treatment?
patient diagnosed with opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be identified in laboratory workup?
16-year-old patient presents with confusion, and MRI shows bilateral white matter changes. What is the most likely diagnosis?

question_text: What is the best way to prevent progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) in patients with MS who will be started on Natalizumab?

options.A: Annual MRI
options.B: Pretreatment JC virus titer levels screen
options.D: Use of corticosteroids prior to Natalizumab initiation

options.A: 30-year-old lady presented to the ER with worsening weakness in all four extremities and sensory symptoms. She was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis three months ago after an episode of optic neuritis and was started on Natalizumab due to highly active disease. Which of the following laboratory investigations should be sent based on the suspected differential diagnosis (NMOSD)?

female patient, known to have relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis and maintained on disease-modifying therapy (DMT), presented with new limb weakness and numbness. The diagnosis of multiple sclerosis was established. She started on high-dose IV Methylprednisolone but showed no improvement. Which of the following is the next step in management?

young female patient presents with right leg weakness and incontinence. An MRI report shows two periventricular lesions, and T1 with contrast shows one lesion enhancing. A whole spine MRI shows T2 multiple small lesions. What is the diagnosis?

question_text: Which of the following is considered a red flag in multiple sclerosis?

options.A: Extensive spinal lesion
options.C: Enhancing lesion present for more than 3 months
options.D: Severe optic neuritis with poor recovery

question_text: In a patient with Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP), what is a common finding in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)?

options.A: Normal protein levels
options.D: Increased white blood cell count with neutrophilic predominance

options.A: 30-year-old male, known case of type 1 diabetes mellitus, presented 3 months ago with optic neuritis and was started on one of the DMTs as a case of multiple sclerosis. He now presents with a 3-day history of blurred vision. Examination and brain MRI are stable compared with previous documentation. Which DMT is likely responsible for this presentation?

question_text: Which of the following disease-modifying therapies (DMT) is known to cause paresthesia?

options.A: Teriflunomide

young female with a previous history of two optic neuritis attacks presents with new symptoms of spinal cord lesions. MRI shows extensive hyperintense T2 lesions from C8-T1, and Aquaporin 4 is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?

young female patient presents with right leg weakness and incontinence. An MRI report shows two periventricular lesions, and T1 with contrast shows one lesion enhancing. A whole spine MRI shows T2 multiple small lesions. What is the next step in management?
young female presented with a typical history of optic neuritis. Brain and spine MRI were normal. What is the risk of conversion to multiple sclerosis (MS)?

question_text: What are the characteristic findings in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of a patient with Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP)?

options.A: Elevated protein with normal cell count
options.B: Elevated white blood cell count with lymphocytic predominance
options.C: Normal protein and elevated cell count

options.A: Start beta-interferon therapy
Elevated serum immunoglobulin A
options.B: Extremely low or absent serum immunoglobulin A

options.A: UA and urine culture
patient presents with a triad of areflexia, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia (Miller Fisher syndrome). What is the recommended treatment?

question_text: In the management of a patient diagnosed with PML, what is the most appropriate step?

options.A: Start antiviral therapy

question_text: In the same scenario [Implicitly related to an MS/NMO context], what is the most likely diagnosis for her condition?

options.A: Relapsing remitting multiple sclerosis

question_text: What is the diagnosis for a patient presenting with symptoms consistent with Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP)?

options.A: AIDP
female patient with a long history of multiple sclerosis (MS) on fingolimod presents with spasticity and gait issues, and her MRI shows no active disease. What should be done next for her gait?

question_text: In a scenario of neuromyelitis optica (NMO) with bilateral optic neuritis and transverse myelitis extending over more than 3 segments, which of the following is most useful for diagnosis?

options.A: MRI of the brain

question_text: Trigeminal neuralgia in young age, diagnosis is best made by:

options.A: MRI
female patient with jaw claudication and temporal headache, who also has joint pain and diffuse muscle ache, what is the next step?

question_text: Which of the following adverse effects is most commonly associated with the first infusion of a B-cell lysis agent?

options.A: Anaphylaxis

55-year-old patient came with left lower limb paresthesia and heaviness that is getting worse, reaching to the upper limb, and intermittent abdominal pain, hyperhidrosis; he received a vaccine 2 weeks ago. What is the diagnosis?

question_text: An elderly patient presents with areflexia (tendon reflex not obtained), ophthalmoplegia, and impaired finger-to-nose test for the past 2 days, with no history of infection or vaccination. What is the likely antibody involved?

options.A: Anti-GQ1b

question_text: An 18-year-old boy presents with vertigo and an exaggerated dermatological reaction during IV insertion. MRI findings are pending. Which condition is most likely associated with these symptoms?

options.A: Behçet's disease
lady presents with personality changes and hearing loss. MRI findings are pending. Which condition is most likely associated with these symptoms?

question_text: Which statement is true regarding multiple sclerosis (MS)?

options.A: Simultaneous bilateral optic neuritis would suggest looking for other diagnoses.
options.B: Incomplete recovery is typical with MS.
options.C: MS lesions are typically found only in the spinal cord.
options.D: MS always presents with a progressive course from onset.

options.A: patient with multiple sclerosis presents with the left eye showing no abduction or adduction, while the right eye has abduction only. What is the likely diagnosis?
patient with MS on fingolimod has an image showing new activity. What is the next step in management?

question_text: In multiple sclerosis (MS), what is the pattern of distribution of lesions?

options.A: Oligodendrocytes cell body

young patient was found to be unresponsive in bed and sleepy but arousable. Upon examination in the emergency room, no focal neurologic deficits were found. An MRI of the brain showed bilateral hyperintensity of the thalamus and the area around the foramen and right insular. What is the most appropriate next step?

On the morning of presentation, she had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. IV acyclovir and phenytoin were started. MRI of the brain and EEG are normal. After three days, her clinical status does not improve. CSF PCR is negative for HSV, VZV, EBV. Which of the following autoantibodies is most likely to be responsible for her presentation?

question_text: What is the mechanism of action of Ocrelizumab?

options.A: CD20 (Same as Rituximab)

patient with multiple sclerosis presents with optic neuritis (ON). The MRI shows one periventricular lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?

question_text: Which of the following is a probable risk factor for multiple sclerosis with an odds ratio of 1.4?

options.A: Low sunlight exposure
young lady with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) complained of seizures and confusion. She has SLE nephritis and is on dialysis. What is your diagnosis?

question_text: What is the best way to diagnose small vessel vasculitis?

options.A: Respond to corticosteroids

question_text: An 18-year-old woman is referred to your office after branch retinal artery occlusion occurred in each eye several months apart. options.A: Multiple sclerosis

options.A: Intracerebral hemorrhage

options.A: Papillitis with papilledema

question_text: Which of the following infections can cause internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO)?

options.A: Multiple Sclerosis

question_text: Which of the following is the most common presentation of Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA)?

options.A: Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION)

question_text: Which one of the following is a feature of optic neuritis due to multiple sclerosis?

options.A: Papillitis with papilledema
key feature associated with optic neuritis in the context of Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is:

young female patient was admitted to the psychiatric ward with non-specific abnormal movements, agitation, and other psychiatric issues. An MRI showed a normal temporal lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Visual anosognosia
young lady presents with persistent nausea and vomiting. Brain MRI is unremarkable. Based on the suspected diagnosis, which criteria is core?
Partial myelitis

options.D: Teriflunomide 14 mg has a better safety profile than interferon

options.A: Perifascicular atrophy

question_text: In the scenario of Kennedy disease (gynecomastia and family history), which of the following is correct?

options.A: High androgen

options.A: Fasciculations

options.A: First decade

options.A: Hip flexion, knee extension & medial leg sensation

question_text: Case of a patient with weak hip adductors, which nerve is affected?

options.A: Obturator

options.B: Ragged-red fibers on Gomori trichrome stain

question_text: Peripheral neuropathy case: what is the antibody?

options.A: Anti MAG

options.A: Addition of benzodiazepines

options.A: Usually mild paralysis

options.A: Serum creatine kinase (CK)

options.A: Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM)
